# About CoronaNet {-}

The CoronaNet Research Project compiles a database on government responses to the corona virus. Our main focus is to collect as much information as we can about the various fine-grained actions governments are taking to defeat the coronavirus. This includes not only gathering information about which governments are responding to the coronavirus, but who they are targeting the policies toward (e.g. other countries), how they are doing it (e.g. travel restrictions, banning exports of masks) and when they are doing it. We aim to make the data publicly available to help move forward social science research on COVID-19.

Together with 150 political and social science scholars from all over the world, we try to make government reactions and policies visible since the January 1st 2020.

 

***

# Detailed, multilevel, and dyadic data {-}

The data will yield detailed information on 

* The level of government responding to the corona virus crisis (e.g. national, regional/state, local/municipal) 

* Specific actions taken (e.g. travel bans, investments in the public health sector, etc.)

* Geographical areas targeted by these measures 

* Who or what they are targeting (e.g. foreigners, ventilators)

* Compliance mechanisms (e.g., mandatory or voluntary) 

* Timing of policy responses.


***
##  Feedback {-}

CoronaNet is an ongoing research project and we aim to publish new data versions on a daily basis. The project is supervised by senior political scientists from NYU Abu Dhabi, TU Munich and Yale, and underlies high-standard validity and reliability checks. If you have any questions regarding the data or you find any inaccuracies, please contact us [here](https://forms.gle/2Zc5Rrdq9J43b7NR9).
